levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Understands the difference between a population and a sample, and can identify potential sources of bias in data collection.
levels.example_task: A school wants to find out students' favourite lunch option. They survey 30 students from the football team. Explain why this sample may be biased.
levels.example_response: The football team may not be representative of the whole school — they might prefer higher-calorie meals. A better sample would be a random selection from all year groups.
common_errors: Not explaining why the sample is unrepresentative
Thinking a larger sample automatically removes bias

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Selects and applies appropriate sampling methods (random, systematic, stratified) and designs data collection tools including questionnaires.
levels.example_task: A school has 600 students: 200 in Year 7, 180 in Year 8, 120 in Year 9, 100 in Year 10. A stratified sample of 50 is needed. How many from each year?
common_errors: Dividing 50 equally between four groups (12 or 13 each)
Not using the population proportions to calculate stratum sizes

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Evaluates sampling methods, identifies limitations of data collection, and designs strategies to minimise bias and improve validity.
levels.example_task: A researcher wants to find out how much time teenagers spend on social media. Compare using an online survey versus face-to-face interviews. Which is better?
levels.example_response: Online survey: larger sample, cheaper, but self-selection bias (only those online will respond, and they may use social media more). Respondents may also exaggerate or underestimate. Face-to-face: more accurate responses (can clarify questions), but smaller sample, more expensive, and social desirability bias (respondents may understate usage). A better approach might be combining a stratified random online survey with follow-up interviews for a subsample.
common_errors: Not identifying specific types of bias for each method
Concluding one method is universally better without considering trade-offs

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Designs complete statistical investigations with appropriate hypotheses, sampling strategies, and evaluates the reliability and validity of conclusions drawn from data.
levels.example_task: Design a statistical investigation to test whether students who eat breakfast perform better in morning tests. Include hypothesis, sampling, data collection and potential confounders.
levels.example_response: Hypothesis: Students who eat breakfast score higher on morning tests than those who do not. Sampling: Stratified random sample across year groups, aiming for 100+ students to ensure adequate power. Data collection: Anonymous questionnaire on breakfast habits (eaten/not eaten, type), plus morning test scores from school records. Confounders: sleep quality, prior attainment, socioeconomic status (linked to both breakfast and attainment). These should be recorded and controlled for in analysis. Limitation: This is observational, not experimental — correlation does not imply causation. Students who eat breakfast may also have other advantages.
common_errors: Not identifying confounding variables
Claiming a causal relationship from observational data

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Constructs and interprets bar charts, pie charts and pictograms accurately, including reading scales and comparing categories.
levels.example_task: A pie chart shows exam results: A* = 36 degrees, A = 72 degrees, B = 108 degrees, C = 90 degrees, D = 54 degrees. There are 200 students. How many got a B?
levels.example_response: B sector = 108 degrees. Fraction = 108/360 = 3/10. Number of students = 3/10 x 200 = 60.
common_errors: Not dividing by 360 (computing 108/200 instead)
Reading the angle incorrectly from the chart

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Constructs and interprets frequency polygons, cumulative frequency graphs (plotting at upper class boundaries), and reads quartiles from cumulative frequency.
levels.example_task: Draw a cumulative frequency graph from: 0-10 (freq 4), 10-20 (freq 12), 20-30 (freq 18), 30-40 (freq 6). Estimate the median.
levels.example_response: Cumulative frequencies: 4, 16, 34, 40. Plot at upper boundaries: (10, 4), (20, 16), (30, 34), (40, 40). Total = 40, so median at 20th value. Reading from the graph: approximately 23.
common_errors: Plotting at midpoints instead of upper class boundaries
Finding the median by looking at frequency 20 on the x-axis instead of the y-axis

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Constructs and interprets histograms with unequal class widths using frequency density, and compares distributions using box plots.
levels.example_task: A histogram has these bars: class 0-5 with frequency density 2, class 5-15 with frequency density 3.5, class 15-20 with frequency density 4. Find the frequency for each class.
levels.example_response: Frequency = frequency density x class width. Class 0-5: 2 x 5 = 10. Class 5-15: 3.5 x 10 = 35. Class 15-20: 4 x 5 = 20. Total = 65.
common_errors: Using the height as the frequency (reading 2, 3.5, 4 as the frequencies)
Not computing class width correctly for unequal intervals

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Interprets and compares complex statistical diagrams critically, including population pyramids, misleading graphs, and composite representations. Constructs histograms from raw grouped data and uses area to estimate probabilities.
levels.example_task: A histogram shows journey times. The class 10-20 has frequency density 3.2 and the class 20-25 has frequency density 4.0. Estimate the probability that a randomly chosen journey takes between 15 and 25 minutes.
levels.example_response: Area for 15-20 (half of the 10-20 bar): 3.2 x 5 = 16. Area for 20-25: 4.0 x 5 = 20. Estimated frequency for 15-25: 16 + 20 = 36. Need total frequency (sum of all bar areas) to compute probability. If total = 120, then P(15 to 25) = 36/120 = 0.3. The key insight is that area represents frequency in a histogram, so we can estimate probabilities from areas.
common_errors: Using height instead of area to estimate frequency from a histogram
Not recognising that the area of a bar (not its height) represents the frequency

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Calculates mean, median, mode and range for small ungrouped data sets and knows which average each one represents.
levels.example_task: Find the mean, median and mode of: 3, 5, 5, 6, 8, 9, 12.
levels.example_response: Mean = (3+5+5+6+8+9+12)/7 = 48/7 = 6.86 (2 d.p.). Median = 6 (middle of 7 ordered values). Mode = 5 (appears twice).
common_errors: Not ordering the data before finding the median
Confusing the position of the median (finding the 3.5th value of 7 items instead of the 4th)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Calculates the mean from a frequency table using sum of fx / sum of f, and chooses the most appropriate average for a given data set.
levels.example_task: Find the mean from: Score 1 (freq 5), Score 2 (freq 8), Score 3 (freq 12), Score 4 (freq 3), Score 5 (freq 2).
common_errors: Dividing by the number of different scores (5) instead of the total frequency (30)
Not multiplying score by frequency before summing

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Estimates the mean from a grouped frequency table using midpoints, finds the modal class, and estimates the median class. Understands why these are estimates.
levels.example_task: Estimate the mean from: 0 < x <= 10 (freq 6), 10 < x <= 20 (freq 14), 20 < x <= 30 (freq 8), 30 < x <= 50 (freq 2).
levels.example_response: Midpoints: 5, 15, 25, 40. Sum of fm = 6(5) + 14(15) + 8(25) + 2(40) = 30 + 210 + 200 + 80 = 520. Sum of f = 30. Estimated mean = 520/30 = 17.3 (1 d.p.). This is an estimate because we assume all values in each class equal the midpoint.
common_errors: Using lower or upper bounds instead of midpoints
Not finding the correct midpoint for the unequal class width 30-50 (midpoint is 40, not 35)

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Uses cumulative frequency to estimate quartiles, interquartile range and percentiles. Compares distributions using summary statistics and evaluates which measures are most appropriate.
levels.example_task: Two factories produce bolts. Factory A: mean diameter 10.02 mm, IQR 0.03 mm. Factory B: mean diameter 10.00 mm, IQR 0.12 mm. The target is 10.00 mm. Which factory is more reliable?
levels.example_response: Factory B has the mean closer to target (10.00 vs 10.02) but much larger variability (IQR 0.12 vs 0.03). Factory A is slightly off-target but very consistent — most bolts are within 0.03 mm of each other. Factory B is centred correctly but produces bolts with wide variation — some could be far from target. Factory A is more reliable for quality control because consistency matters more than being exactly centred (which can be recalibrated). The small systematic error in A is preferable to the large random error in B.
common_errors: Only comparing means without considering spread
Not interpreting IQR in context — just stating 'Factory A has smaller IQR' without explaining the practical implication

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Plots scatter graphs from paired data and describes the overall trend informally (going up, going down, no pattern).
levels.example_task: Plot these points on a scatter graph: (150, 45), (155, 50), (160, 55), (165, 52), (170, 60), (175, 58), (180, 65). Describe the trend.
levels.example_response: The points show an upward trend: as height increases, weight tends to increase. The relationship is not perfect — not all points lie on a straight line.
common_errors: Joining the dots with a line (scatter graphs show individual points, not connected lines)
Not using appropriate scales on both axes

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifies and describes the type and strength of correlation (strong/weak positive, strong/weak negative, none) and draws a line of best fit by eye.
levels.example_task: A scatter graph shows that as the age of a car increases, its value decreases. There is a clear downward trend with points close to a line. Describe the correlation.
levels.example_response: There is a strong negative correlation: as the age of the car increases, its value tends to decrease. A line of best fit would slope downward. The strong correlation means the points are close to the line, so age is a good predictor of value.
common_errors: Describing the correlation as 'negative' without commenting on strength
Drawing the line of best fit through two extreme points instead of balancing it through the middle of the data

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Uses a line of best fit to make predictions, distinguishing between interpolation (reliable, within data range) and extrapolation (unreliable, outside data range).
levels.example_task: A line of best fit for height (cm) vs shoe size has equation y = 0.1x - 7, valid for heights 150-190 cm. Estimate the shoe size for (a) height 170 cm, (b) height 210 cm.
levels.example_response: (a) y = 0.1(170) - 7 = 17 - 7 = size 10. This is interpolation (170 is within the data range 150-190) so the estimate is reliable. (b) y = 0.1(210) - 7 = 21 - 7 = size 14. This is extrapolation (210 is outside the data range) so the estimate is unreliable — the linear relationship may not hold for very tall people.
common_errors: Treating extrapolated predictions as equally reliable to interpolated ones
Not checking whether the prediction value falls within or outside the data range

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Critically evaluates bivariate data, distinguishes correlation from causation, identifies lurking variables, and interprets the equation and gradient of a line of best fit in context.
levels.example_task: A study finds a strong positive correlation between ice cream sales and drowning incidents. A newspaper headline says 'Ice cream causes drowning'. Evaluate this claim.
levels.example_response: The claim is false — it confuses correlation with causation. The lurking (confounding) variable is temperature/season: hot weather causes both increased ice cream sales and increased swimming (leading to more drowning incidents). The two variables are associated because they share a common cause, not because one causes the other. To establish causation, you would need a controlled experiment (impossible here for ethical reasons). This is a classic example of a spurious correlation driven by a confounding variable.
common_errors: Accepting the causal claim because the correlation is strong
Not identifying the confounding variable (temperature/weather)
